chunks.original_text: 道经下 李约注 太上，下知有之； 远古之君，民下知有之尔，未尝闻其令也。 其次，亲之誉之； 蒙德故亲之，沐仁故誉之。 其次，畏之侮之。 直者畏之，奸者侮之。 信不足，有不信。 初以伪诱之，是信不足也。 后以诚示之，人亦不之信。 犹其贵言。 不知贵言贱信，已至斯弊，犹贵其言，则淳和之风不可至也。 功成事遂，百姓谓我自然。 由无教令，是有此俗。 大道废，有仁义； 大道非欲避仁义而废之，而仁义立，故大道不得不废，由时舍本崇末也。 智慧出，有大伪； 智慧出，非欲兴大伪，而大伪不得不兴，为凭迹而生也。 六亲不和，有孝慈； 父慈子孝之日，岂有曾参之名？ 国家昏乱，有忠臣。 君贤臣良之时，焉有比干之节？ 绝圣弃智，民利百倍； 绝圣弃智，则无法令。 无法令，则民不忧其抵犯。 民不忧其抵犯，则恣而为生，与其名韩之时，而计其利不啻百倍。 绝仁弃义，民复孝慈； 绝膻行之仁义，则天下不奉不及之法，皆复於自然孝慈。 绝巧弃利，盗贼无有。 绝越常之巧，则其利均。 其利均，则民各足。 民各足，则谁为盗贼？ 此三者，以为文未足，故令有所属。 属，继也。 三者足以教君，夫足以教民，故更继四句。 见素去染也。 抱朴，守本也。 少私忘己也。 寡欲。 丧偶也。 绝学无忧。 若为人间之学，举措皆有悔吝，故忧之。 唯之与阿，相去几何？ 唯阿同出於口，便有喜怒之变。 善之与恶，相去何若？ 善恶同生於心，岂有胡越之远。 人之所畏，不可不畏。 人之所畏者，当须畏之，若不畏则祸患立至。 荒兮其未央哉。 世人之学，学皆如此，则自然之性，日向荒凉，未有休止之势也。 众人熙熙，殉欲之貌。 如享太牢，贪可知也。 如登春台。 增淫志也。 我独怕兮其未兆，如婴儿之未孩。 老子云：我於人间之学绝来已久，今纵见之，情实怕然，未有兆朕，似婴儿之未孩者，未识人之意也。 乘乘兮，若无所归。 乘乘者，乘其所乘也。 圣人无心，所遇便乘之而往，安知彼之与此，而谓之归。 众人皆有余，於俗学皆似有余力。 我独若遗。 唯我於俗学，则似神不足而遗忘。 我愚人之心也哉，非也。 纯纯兮。 素朴未散，故耳。 俗人察察，骋严朋也。 我独闷闷； 似无能也。 俗人昭昭，矜有知也。 我独若昏。 若藏端也。 忽若海，寂兮似独所止。 如虚舟之泛泛兮，在巨海之中未尝有所止泊者也。 众人皆有以，是故不闲。 我独顽似鄙。 我独不知有人间之事，其庸顽也如边鄙之民。 我独异於人，形同人群，心游物表。 而贵求食於母。 母，道也。 食饲也。 我所以独异於人者，为求饲於道也。 道亦以我能绝俗学，故常以元和妙气而饲之。 孔德之容，唯道之从。 孔，甚也。 容，受也。 从，顺也。 其有德之人，其心清虚，唯容受至道，从顺而行之。 道之为物，唯恍唯惚。 道之为物，虽恍惚无常，然恶烦杂而托清虚也。 惚兮恍兮，其中有象； 惚，无也。 恍，有也。 其中者，其中心也。 象，罔象也。 若其心中从惚兮无物，而为恍兮有欲，则其道化为罔象也。 恍兮惚兮，其中有物。 若其心中从恍兮有欲，而能为惚兮无欲，则其道复化为妙物，湛然居於心中也。 窈兮冥兮，其中有精，窈，深也。 冥，暗也。 精，道之妙也。 言道以精妙之气，出入於万物之中，莫见其

**The *Dao De Jing* (Lower Section) – Li Ye’s Annotation**

The Sage-King knows what is beneath;
The ancient rulers were known only by their subjects—
They never issued decrees.

Next, they were loved and praised;
They were loved because of their virtue,
Praised because of their benevolence.

Next, they were feared and reviled;
The upright feared them,
The deceitful reviled them.

When trust is lacking, distrust arises.
At first, they lured with falsehood—
This is why trust was lacking.
Later, they showed sincerity—
Yet people still did not believe them.

They still valued words.
Not knowing that words should be valued less than trust,
They reached this ruin—
Yet they still valued words,
So the pure and harmonious winds could not prevail.

When deeds were accomplished and affairs settled,
The people said, *"It happened naturally."*
Because there were no teachings or laws,
This custom arose.

When the Great Dao declined, there were benevolence and righteousness;
The Great Dao did not decline to avoid benevolence and righteousness,
But because benevolence and righteousness were established,
The Great Dao had no choice but to decline—
For it was the age of abandoning the root to exalt the branches.

When wisdom arose, great deceit followed;
Wisdom did not arise to foster great deceit,
But great deceit could not help but arise—
Because it relied on traces to take form.

When the six kinsfolk were not harmonious, filial piety and kindness emerged;
On days when fathers were kind and sons filial,
Would there be the fame of Zeng Shen?
When states were chaotic and corrupt, loyal ministers arose.
In times when rulers were virtuous and ministers upright,
Where would the resolve of Bi Gan come from?

To abandon the sage and discard wisdom,
The people’s benefits increase a hundredfold;
To abandon the sage and discard wisdom
Is to have no laws or decrees.
With no laws or decrees,
The people need not fear transgression.
When the people fear no transgression,
They act freely in life—
Compared to the time of Han Xin’s calculations,
Their gains are not merely a hundredfold.

To abandon benevolence and discard righteousness,
The people return to natural filial piety and kindness;
To abandon the artificial benevolence and righteousness,
The world does not uphold the unattainable laws—
All return to natural filial piety and kindness.

To abandon cleverness and discard profit,
Thieves and robbers vanish.
To abandon extraordinary cleverness,
Then profit is balanced.
When profit is balanced,
Then the people each have enough.
When the people each have enough,
Who would become thieves and robbers?

These three [principles] are insufficient for cultivation,
So four more are added.
*Seeing* the unadorned and discarding stains—
Embracing simplicity, guarding the root—
Fewer desires, forgetting self—
Few desires.
Losing the paired—
Discarding artificial distinctions.

To abandon learning and have no worries.
If one studies worldly affairs,
Every action brings regret and hesitation—
Thus, there is worry.
*"Yes"* and *"Ah"*—how far apart are they?
*"Yes"* and *"Ah"* arise from the mouth,
Yet bring changes of joy and anger.
Good and evil—how far apart are they?
Good and evil arise from the heart—
How distant is it from the Hu-Yueh divide?

What people fear, one must fear.
What people fear, one must truly fear—
If not, calamity will arise.

Wild and endless—
The learning of the world is like this:
The natural disposition grows daily more desolate,
With no end in sight.

The multitude bustles and thrives,
Pursuing desires like feasting on the grandest sacrifice.
Like ascending the Spring Terrace—
Their lustful desires only grow.

I alone stand in dread, as yet unmanifest,
Like an infant before it speaks.
Laozi said:
*"I have long abandoned worldly learning.
Now, even seeing it, I am filled with dread—
It has not yet taken form,
Like an infant before it speaks,
Not yet knowing human intentions."*

Steadfast and unyielding—
As if having nowhere to return.
*Steadfast* means riding what one rides.
The Sage has no intent—
Whatever is encountered, they ride it forward.
How would they know to distinguish this from that
And call it returning?

The multitude all have excess—
In worldly learning, they seem to have surplus strength.
I alone seem abandoned.
Only I, in worldly learning,
Seem as if divine insufficiency has left me forgotten.

I am the heart of the foolish—
No, it is not.
Pure and unadorned—
The simple and unrefined have not yet scattered—
Thus, it is called *pure*.
The vulgar are sharp and discerning,
Exhibiting rigid friendships.
I alone am muddled—
As if lacking ability.
The vulgar are bright and clear,
Boasting knowledge.
I alone seem dim—
As if hiding the essence.
Vast as the sea, tranquil and solitary—
Like a hollow boat drifting on the great waters,
Never stopping or anchoring.

The multitude all have purpose—
Thus, they are not at ease.
I alone seem dull and crude—
I alone do not know of worldly affairs,
My stupidity like that of the border folk.

I alone differ from others—
In form, like the crowd;
In heart, wandering beyond things.

Yet I value nourishment from the Mother.
The Mother is the Dao.
Nourishment is sustenance.
What makes me differ from others
Is that I seek sustenance from the Dao.
The Dao, because I can abandon worldly learning,
Often nourishes me with the original harmony and subtle qi.

The vast virtue’s capacity—
Only the Dao follows it.
*Vast* means extreme.
*Capacity* means reception.
*Follows* means to conform.
Those with virtue,
Their hearts pure and empty,
Only receive the supreme Dao
And follow it in action.

The Dao, as a thing,
Is only vague and indistinct.
The Dao, though vague and indistinct, is not without form—
*Vague* means absence.
*Indistinct* means presence.
*Within* refers to the heart.
*Form* means the boundless form.
If the heart is vague—
Without things—
Yet becomes indistinct—
With desires—
Then the Dao transforms into boundless form.

If the heart is indistinct—
With desires—
Yet returns to vague—
Without desires—
Then the Dao transforms back into wondrous things,
Deeply dwelling within the heart.

Profound and dark—
Within it is essence.
*Profound* means deep.
*Dark* means obscure.
*Essence* is the Dao’s wonder.
Speaking of the Dao’s wondrous qi,
Entering and exiting all things,
Yet unseen—

rget itself.

The Dao endures forever;
If one forgets the sovereign’s principle,
How can one’s blessings and longevity be feared?
One’s body may perish, yet no harm befalls.

Love extends even to the Sweet Osage,
Yet will one wash away its people?
To say that the ultimate person
Establishes deeds, affairs, teachings, and laws,
Enduring through all ages—
When the body departs, the spirit remains.

**The New Annotations of the *Zhenjing of Dao and Virtue* conclude, Volume One. Volume Two begins.**

chunks.original_text: 朕，唯虚心者能得之。 其精甚真，得不假之精，遂成真人也。 其中有信。 诚能虚心，则精应不失也。 自古及今，其名不去，古犹今也，今人虚感应其不失，因知古之感者其应亦然也。 以阅众甫。 阅，寻阅也。 甫，始也，。 寻阅古始，得道者众矣，一一皆以无欲而得之矣。 吾何以知众甫之然？ 以此。 老子曰：我何以知得道之人如此？ 以其上事而知之矣。 曲则全，无所不顺，孰为我害？ 枉则直，屈如不言，终必自申。 洼则盈，唯下下者，天下归心。 弊则新，不重所得，方能进修。 少则得，不分其志。 多则惑。 好殉群方。 是以圣人抱一为天下式。 唯守道而已，天下不敢违。 不自见，故明； 晦己能，能必昭也。 不自是，故彰； 亡己是，是必着矣。 不自矜，故长； 以短自与，而长反归。 不自伐，故有功。 夫唯不居，是以不去。 夫唯不争，天下莫能与之争。 其行如前，则无不伏。 古之所谓曲则全者，岂虚言哉？ 诚全而归之。 但行之当，自见其效。 希言自然。 慎言者，不唯寡尤，亦乃合自然之道也。 飘风不终朝，骤雨不终日。 此二者伤物太甚，故不可久为。 孰为此者？ 天地。 天地尚不能久，而况於人乎？ 天地有形之至大者，为暴风疾雨损於物，犹不敢久为，而瓦至细之人而欲多言伤自然之气乎？ 故从事於道者，希言者，其人也。 道者同於道，德者同於德，失者同於失。 各以其类会也。 同於道者，道亦得之； 同於德者，德亦得之； 同於失者，失亦得之。 同类相遇，皆相得也。 信不足，有不信。 不信希言合道，而以多言获戾，则悔而求之，虽发丹诚，而从事於道之人，亦不足信也。 跂者不立，跂踵之浪，不堪持久。 跨者不行。 跨阔其足，安能致远？ 自见者不明，自是者不彰，自伐者无功，自矜者不长。 由跂者跨者生自见等行，是皆妄作，且越天真，有一於身，则为人伦之弃物，况兼之乎？ 其於道也，曰余食赘行。 其可恶也，如食之残，如形之剩肉也。 物或恶之，故有道者不处。 凡庸之物，犹或致嫌，则有道之人固不留意於此。 有物混成，先天地生。 元气圆凝之时，未有天地也。 寂兮寥兮，至虚至静。 独立而不改，不与物群，复不随物化也。 周行而不殆，备行万物之中，又无时而危也。 可以为天下母。 为能生育。 吾不知其名，无得而称。 强字之曰道，字以表德，为有生天生地之德，故字道以表之。 强名之曰大。 名以召实，为其无所不包，故名曰大。 以示於人人欲修之，当有所谓矣。 大曰逝，已不在大。 逝日远，又逝处复失也。 远曰返。 远追之不获，俄然返於虚心也。 故道大，天大，地大，王亦大。 王虽不得比於三大，其为大也亦次之。 域中有四大，而王居其一焉。 道已下三大，皆自道而生。 王已上三大，皆令王法则。 人法地地，地体静载而生物，法之者令与地同，同地故云地地也。 法天天，天德广覆而无私，法之者令与天同，同天故云天天也。 法道道，道性忘功，法之者令与道同，同道故云道道也。 法自然。 人能法三者，皆与为一，始可称王尔，则为万人之中一人尔。 言地天道三者，皆有自然妙理，王者当法之尔。 自然理者，是覆载生成皆不私也。 重为轻根，万物莫不由根而生者，为根重也。 静为躁君。
chunks.translated_text:
The **sovereign**—
Only the one with a **void-heart** can attain it.

Its **essence** is most **true**,
Obtaining the **unborrowed essence**,
Thus becoming a **True Person**.

Within it is **faith**.
If one’s **sincerity** can void the heart,
Then the **essence** will respond and not be lost.

From ancient times to now,
Its name does not fade—
Ancient is just like the present,
And the present person, sensing its response,
Knows that the ancients’ sensing was likewise.

**Observe the multitude of beginnings**—
*Observe* means to **search and verify**.
*Beginnings* mean the **first stirrings**.

Searching and verifying ancient origins,
Those who attained the Dao were many—
Each and all obtained it through **desirelessness**.

How do I know this of the multitude of beginnings?
Thus:

The **Laozi** said:
How do I know those who attain the Dao are such?
By their **highest actions**, I recognize them.

**Bend** and you are **whole**—
Nothing is unyielding,
Who can harm you?
**Crooked** makes you **straight**—
**Flexing** yet silent,
Ultimately, it will **self-express**.

**Low** and you are **full**—
Only the **lowest of the low**,
And the world’s heart is drawn to them.

**Worn** and you are **renewed**—
Not clinging to what you’ve gained,
Only then can you **advance and refine**.

**Few** and you **attain**—
Not dividing your **intent**.
**Many** and you are **bewildered**.

They love to **follow the crowd**—
Thus the **sage** embraces **Oneness** as the **model for all under heaven**,
Only adhering to the Dao,
And none under heaven dare defy.

Not **self-revealing**, so **clear**;
**Hide** your **capacity**, and it will **inevitably shine**.
Not **self-righteous**, so **illuminated**;
**Lose** your **self-righteousness**, and it will **become apparent**.

Not **self-proud**, so **long-lasting**;
**Offering** your **shortcomings**, your **length** returns.
Not **self-praising**, so **fruitful**.

Only the one who **does not dwell** upon it,
Thus does not **abandon** it.
Only the one who **does not contend**,
None under heaven can **contend with** them.

Their **conduct** is as **flexible as water**,
And none dare **not submit**.

What was called **"Bend and you are whole"**—
Is it not a **hollow phrase**?
It is **whole** and **returns**—
Only act **appropriately**, and the **effect** will **self-manifest**.
**Sparse speech** is **natural**.

The **cautious in speech**,
Not only **few in blame**,
But also **harmonize with the Dao’s natural Way**.

**Gales** do not last the morning,
**Sudden rains** do not last the day.
These two, **injuring things** too severely,
Thus cannot endure long.

Who does this?
**Heaven and Earth**.
Heaven and Earth, though **greatest in form**,
Are **spoiled by violent winds and torrential rains**,
Yet dare not **endure long**.
How much more so for **humans**—
With **utterances** so **abundant**,
Yet **harming the Dao’s natural qi**?

Thus, those who **pursue the Dao**,
**Sparse in speech**—
Such is the **true person**.

**Daoists** align with **Dao**,
**Virtuous ones** align with **virtue**,
**Lost ones** align with **loss**.
Each **gathers their own kind**.

Align with **Dao**, and **Dao** will **align with you**;
Align with **virtue**, and **virtue** will **align with you**;
Align with **loss**, and **loss** will **align with you**.

**Kindred** meet—
All **find accord**.

**Faith** insufficient,
There will be **doubt**.
**Doubt** **sparse speech** **harmonizing with Dao**,
Yet **seeking** **retribution through many words**,
Then **regret** and **seek** it—
Even if you **utter sincere resolve**,
Those who **pursue the Dao** will still not **trust you**.

**Stilted** cannot **stand**—
**Stilted heels**,
Cannot **endure long**.
**Striding** cannot **walk**—
**Striding wide**, how can you **reach far**?

**Self-revealing** is **not clear**,
**Self-righteous** is **not illuminated**,
**Self-praising** is **not fruitful**,
**Self-proud** is **not long-lasting**.

From **stilted** and **striding** arise **self-revealing** and such **conducts**—
These are all **empty actions**,
And **transgressing the natural**,
One **fault** in the **body**,
And you become **cast out by humanity**—
How much more so if **both** are present?

In **Dao**, it is called **"excess food, superfluous limbs"**—
Its **repulsiveness**,
Like **leftover food**,
Like **excess flesh** on the **form**.

**Things** may **abhor** it,
Thus **Daoists** are **unsettled**.

Common **trivialities**,
Even **susceptible to objection**,
Yet **Daoists** **do not dwell** upon these.

There is a **thing** **mixed and complete**,
Born before **Heaven and Earth**.
When **Original Qi** **condenses and congeals**,
Not yet **Heaven and Earth**.

**Silent** and **vast**—
**Supreme void**, **supreme stillness**.
**Standing alone**, yet **unchanging**,
Not **mingling with things**,
Nor **following things’ transformations**.

**Circulating endlessly**, yet **never exhausted**,
**Fully manifesting** within **all things**,
And **never** at **risk** at any time.

It can be the **mother of all under heaven**—
**Capable of nurturing and giving birth**.

I **do not know** its name,
No **attainment** to **call** it by.
**Forcibly** name it **Dao**—
*Dao* to **express virtue**,
For it possesses the **virtue of giving birth to Heaven and Earth**,
Thus **name it Dao** to **express** it.

**Forcibly** name it **Great**—
*Great* to **summon reality**,
For it **embodies nothing**—
Thus **name it Great**.

To **demonstrate** to **all people** who wish to **cultivate**,
There will be **what is called**.

**Great** is **passing**—
Once **passed**, it is **no longer in Greatness**.
**Passing** is **far**—
And **passing** again **loses its place**.
**Far** is **return**—
**Pursuing** the **far** is **unattainable**,
Suddenly **returning** to the **void-heart**.

Thus, **Dao is Great**,
**Heaven is Great**,
**Earth is Great**,
And the **King** is also **Great**.
Though the **King** cannot **compare** with the **Three Great**,
Their **greatness** is **ranked below**.

Within the **domain** are the **Four Great**,
And the **King** occupies **one** of them.

**Dao**, having **descended** to the **Three Great**,
All **originate from Dao**.
The **King**, having **ascended** above the **Three Great**,
All **order the King’s laws**.

**Humans follow Earth**—
Earth’s **virtue** is **stillness and bearing** while **giving birth to things**,
Those who **follow** it **make it like Earth**,
Thus called **"Earth-Earth"** for **Earth’s likeness**.

**Follow Heaven**—
Heaven’s **virtue** is **broad coverage without partiality**,
Those who **follow** it **make it like Heaven**,
Thus called **"Heaven-Heaven"** for **Heaven’s likeness**.

**Follow Dao**—
Dao’s **nature** is **forgetting merit**,
Those who **follow** it **make it like Dao**,
Thus called **"Dao-Dao"** for **Dao’s likeness**.

**Follow the natural**—
If **humans** can **follow** the **Three**,
All **become One**,
Then you can be called **King**,
And you are **one person among ten thousand**.

Speaking of **Earth, Heaven, Dao**—
The **Three**, all possess **natural wondrous principles**,
The **King** should **follow** them.

**Natural principles**—
This is **covering and bearing**, **generating and completing**, yet **not partial**.
**Stillness** is the **root of agitation**,
All things **generate from roots**—
Because **roots are heavy**.

chunks.original_text: 故兆民未有不受制於君者，为君静也。 是以君子行终日不离辎重。 君子欲有所诣，必先备其辎重，用防寒暑饥乏之患。 虽有荣观，燕处超然。 超然者，超脱之貌也。 荣观，春台也，燕燕尔也，治容之所也，此皆守重静者之能超脱者也。 奈何万乘之主而以身轻天下。 物之与人皆守重静，如何天下之主不重其身，轻其出入也。 轻则失臣，轻其举措则难服事，故失臣心。 躁则失君。 躁其情性，不自安静，则失其君位。 善行无辙迹，行道无迹。 善言无瑕谪，言道无谪。 善计不用筹算，守清静，不假筹算。 善闭无关楗而不可开，闭七窍诸门，群魔不能入。 善结无绳约而不可解。 清五脏诸神，外物不能诱。 是以圣人常善救人，故无弃人； 常善救物，故无弃物。 潜行如上之善，道被草木，而而况人乎？ 。 是谓袭明。 内行而外不见。 故善人，不善人之师； 善人能以善与人也。 不善人，善人之资。 资，给也。 不善人是善人可资之物者也。 不贵其师，不爱其资，皆至於道，遂相忘也。 虽知大迷，是谓要妙。 忘师资，俗以为迷，道以为妙也。 知其雄，守其雌，为天下溪。 有雄武之材而不用，能雌伏以为心，则为众所归，如天下深溪也。 为天下溪，常德不离，谦德不离其身，则如溪为百川所凑。 复归於婴兄。 和气充具。 知其白，守其黑，为天下式。 式者，法也。 韬白如黑，则天下之人，罔敢不伏。 为天下式，常德不忒，抱此晦用之德，於身常无差失。 复归於无极。 其德若此，故福寿不可量。 知其荣，守其辱，为天下谷。 以荣如辱，则其量如谷，无所不容纳也。 为天下谷，常德乃足，量无不容，德无不备，复归於朴。 朴，器之本也，德备则能返本。 本，道也。 朴散则为器，器周於用者，道散则众器成焉。 圣人用之则为官长，圣人用道，居群材之上，理化其不明道者。 故大制不割。 怀至道，故能制服生灵，当以无为守之，非加刑法也。 将欲取天下而为之，取天下之欢心。 吾见其不得已。 以有为取之，我见此必不得已。 已，语助也。 天下神器，不可为也。 神器者，人也。 身中居神，所以谓之神器。 人性恶扰，有为则扰人，故知不可以取天下。 为者败之，为之则民散也。 执者失之。 不信厚言，固守本意，则必失帝业。 故物或行或随，若行有为於前，必败失随其后。 或呴或吹，仁德曰陶，严刑曰吹。 或强或羸，民安则强，民散则羸。 或载或隳。 抚之则载，虐之则隳。 是以圣人去甚，去奢，去泰。 有为之验若此之甚，为天下者恶得不去之哉？ 以圣人之为理，则就其中去甚者、奢者与泰者。 以道佐人主者，不以兵强天下，古善为相者，安民强国，则以道不以兵。 其事好还。 克敌之师，师踵未还，已为所报。 师之所处，荆棘生焉。 妨耕耨，故荆棘是生。 大军之后，必有凶年。 战伐之后，杀气犹凝，冲和未行，不产嘉谷也。 故善之果而已，不敢以取强。 佐君合以道，不合以兵。 必不得已，则择其善将者，则必果敢不以好胜为心也。 果而勿矜，果而勿伐，果而勿骄，果而不得已，是果而勿强。 若使善者将甲讨难，必定不矜、不伐、不骄，何谓也？ 为果以谦，不果以强，强则违道。 物壮财老，是谓不道。 物至壮则老，兵至於强未必不败，皆为不合道也。
chunks.translated_text:
「Thus all ten thousand people are without fail subject to the rule of the **King**,
For the **King** embodies **stillness**.

Therefore, the **King**’s conduct never strays from his **wagons and provisions** throughout the day.
The **King** who seeks to achieve anything must first prepare his **wagons and provisions**,
To guard against the miseries of cold, heat, hunger, and want.

Though there are palaces of splendor and places of leisure,
He remains detached and serene.
Detached and serene—
This is the appearance of **transcending and releasing**.
**Palaces of splendor** are the Spring Platforms,
**Places of leisure** are where the **burning** (燕) birds dwell,
These are all the **abodes of refinement** (治容).
Those who uphold **stillness** and **substance** can truly **transcend and release**.

Yet how can the sovereign of a **ten-thousand chariot** realm treat his own body so lightly before the people?
All things, both **humans** and **non-humans**, uphold **stillness** and **substance**—
How can the ruler of the realm not value his own body,
Yet make his comings and goings so **light**?

**Lightness** leads to losing his **ministers**,
**Lightness** in his actions makes governance difficult,
Thus he loses the **hearts of his ministers**.
**Agitation** leads to losing his **Kingdom**.
If his **emotions and nature** are **agitated**,
And he does not **settle himself in stillness**,
Then he will lose his **Kingdom**.

**Good conduct** leaves no trace,
**Following Dao** leaves no trace.
**Good speech** has no flaws or censure,
**Speaking of Dao** has no censure.
**Good calculation** does not rely on tools or reckoning—
**Upholding stillness and purity**, he needs no tools or reckoning.
**Good closure** requires no locks or bars yet cannot be opened—
**Closing** the seven orifices and all gates,
No **demons** can enter.
**Good binding** requires no cords or knots yet cannot be undone—
**Purifying** the five **zang** organs and all **spirits**,
External things cannot tempt him.

Thus, the **Sage** is always **good at rescuing people**,
Hence there are none he **abandons**;
Always **good at rescuing things**,
Hence there are none he **abandons**.
**Hidden actions** like those above—
The **Dao** permeates even **grass and trees**,
How much more so among **humans**?

This is called **"Covering Brightness"**.
**Inner conduct** yet **no outward display**.
Thus, the **good person** is the **teacher** of the **not-good person**;
The **good person** can **give goodness** to others.
The **not-good person** is the **material** of the **good person**.
**Material** means **supplying**.
The **not-good person** is what the **good person** can **supply** with.
If one does not **honor his teacher**,
Or **love his material**,
Both reach **Dao**,
And then **forget each other**.

Though knowing **great confusion**,
This is called **"Essential Marvel"**.
**Forgetting teacher and material**—
The common people call it **confusion**,
But **Dao** calls it **marvelous**.

Know **its masculine**,
Yet **guard its feminine**—
Then you become the **deep valley** of the world.
Though you possess **masculine and martial** talents,
If you **feminine and subdue** them as your **heart**,
Then all will **gather to you**,
Like the world’s **deep valleys**.

To be the **deep valley** of the world—
**Constant virtue** never departs,
**Humility’s virtue** never leaves your body,
Then you are like a **valley** where all **streams** converge.

Return again to the **Infant Brother**.
**Harmonious qi** fills the **body**.

Know **its white**,
Yet **guard its black**—
Then you become the **model** of the world.
**Model** means **law**.
**Concealing white as black**,
Then all under heaven dare not but **submit**.

To be the **model** of the world—
**Constant virtue** never errs,
**Embrace this virtue of obscurity and use it**,
And your body will always be **without fault**.
Return again to **Non-Extremity**.

Its **virtue** is such—
Thus **blessings and longevity** are **unmeasurable**.

Know **its glory**,
Yet **guard its disgrace**—
Then you become the **valley** of the world.
If you **treat glory as disgrace**,
Then your **measure** is like a **valley**,
**Accepting all without distinction**.

To be the **valley** of the world—
**Constant virtue** is then **sufficient**,
**Measure** without exclusion,
**Virtue** without deficiency,
Return again to **Non-Extremity**.
**Non-Extremity** is the **origin** of all **vessels**,
When **virtue is complete**, it can **return to origin**.
**Origin** is **Dao**.
**Non-Extremity** **scattered** becomes **vessels**,
**Vessels** **circumscribed** by **use**—
**Dao** **scattered** then all **vessels** are formed.

The **Sage** **uses** it and becomes **officials and leaders**,
The **Sage** **uses Dao**,
Standing above all **talents**,
**Guiding and transforming** those who do not **know the bright Dao**.
Thus, **great governance** does not **sever**.

**Holding** the **Great Dao**,
Thus he can **govern and subdue** all **living beings**,
He must **guard it with Non-Action**,
Not **adding punishments or laws**.

If one intends to **take the world** yet does so,
He seeks the **world’s favor**—
I see this as **inevitable failure**.

If one **takes with Action**,
I see this will **inevitably fail**.
**Inevitable** is a **grammatical particle**.

The **world** is a **divine vessel**—
It cannot be **taken by force**.
**Divine vessel** means **human**.
**Humans** **inhabit spirits**,
Thus called **divine vessel**.
**Human nature** is **evil and chaotic**,
**Action** **disturbs** people,
Thus it is known that one cannot **take the world by force**.

**Action** leads to **ruin**,
**Forcing** leads to **people scattering**.
**Grasping** leads to **losing it**,
If one **does not trust** **profound words**,
And **clings stubbornly** to his **original intent**,
Then he will **inevitably lose** the **imperial realm**.

Thus, **things** either **move** or **follow**,
If **Action** is **pursued** before,
It will **inevitably lead to ruin** and **losing those who follow**.

Either **breathing** or **blowing**,
**Ren’s virtue** is called **breathing** (陶),
**Severe punishment** is called **blowing**.
Either **strong** or **weak**,
When the **people are at ease**, they are **strong**,
When the **people scatter**, they are **weak**.
Either **supporting** or **overthrowing**,
**Caressing** them leads to **supporting**,
**Cruelty** leads to **overthrowing**.

Thus the **Sage** **removes excess**,
**Removes extravagance**,
**Removes excessiveness**.
The **verification** of **Action** is so **excessive**,
How can the **ruler of the world** not **remove it**?

With the **Sage’s governance**,
He **approaches** those within it who **remove excess**,
**Remove extravagance**,
And **excessiveness**.

**Assisting** the **sovereign** with **Dao**,
Not **assisting** with **arms**.
The **ancient** **good advisors**,
**Calming the people** and **strengthening the realm**,
Then **Dao** is used, not **arms**.

Their **affairs** **love to return**.
The **victorious general**,
His **army’s footsteps** not yet **returned**,
Already **reported** by the enemy.
Where the **army** **dwells**,
**Thorns and brambles** **grow**.
**Obstructing** farming and **weeding**,
Thus **thorns and brambles** **grow**.
After a **great army**,
There will **inevitably** be **years of hardship**.
After **warfare and slaughter**,
The **killing qi** still **lingers**,
**Harmony and balance** have not yet **restored**,
No **fine grains** will **sprout**.

Thus, **goodness’s fruit** is **all that is pursued**,
And one **dares not** to **take by force**.
**Assisting** the **sovereign** **must align** with **Dao**,
Not **align** with **arms**.
If **inevitable failure**,
Then **choose** his **good generals**,
Who **must** be **resolute** yet **not** **pursue victory** for its own sake.

**Resolute** yet **not arrogant**,
**Resolute** yet **not boastful**,
**Resolute** yet **not proud**,
**Resolute** yet **inevitable failure**—
This is **resolute** yet **not forcing**.
If a **good general** leads **armored soldiers** to **punish evil**,
He **must** be **resolute** yet **not arrogant**,
**Not boastful**,
**Not proud**—
Why?
For **resoluteness** comes from **humility**,
Not **resoluteness** from **forcing**.
**Forcing** is **contrary to Dao**.

**Things** reach **peak strength** yet **grow old**—
This is called **"Not Dao"**.
**Things** reach **peak strength** yet **grow old**,
**Arms** reach **peak strength** yet **not necessarily** **victory**,
All are **contrary to Dao**.

All **become One**,

chunks.original_text: 不道早已。 知不合道，能早止者，善矣。 已，止也。 夫隹兵者，不祥之器，隹，好也。 兵，五兵也。 兵为害器，隹好非善。 物或恶之，故有道者不处。 物皆好生恶死，有好兵之国，凡物尚恶之，况有道之士，焉肯居其国也？ 君子居则贵 左，君子体仁以长人，居必贵於发生之位也。 用兵则贵右。 主兵者，以杀为志，故用必贵於摇落之方。 兵者，不祥之器，非君子之器，君子器以文德，不以干戈。 不得已而用之，非其器而用之，盖不得已也。 恬淡为上。 所用之以止寇，殊不得其滋味。 胜而不美，以恬淡为上，故以胜为不美。 而美之者，是乐杀人。 乐，爱也。 若以胜为美，则是爱杀人也。 夫乐杀人者，不可得志於天下。 人咸恶死，孰肯景附？ 故吉事尚左，凶事尚右。 各从其类。 偏将军处左，虽为主杀之官，而无主杀之权。 上将军处右，专於征伐。 言以丧礼处之。 依置柩之所。 杀人众多，以悲哀泣之，君子为将，则曰：我实无德，民有何辜，一朝杀伤，殆至於死。 故兴言而涕从也。 战胜以丧礼处之。 使居其位，不必衣其服，一则顺其杀气，二则抑用兵者之心也。 道常无名，今谓之道，是强名也。 朴虽小，所以视之不见。 天下不敢臣。 怀其道，尚为王者师，况敢以道为臣妾者乎？ 侯王若能守，天下将自宾。 宾，服也，守道不忘则无远不服。 天地相合，以降甘露，天地交泰，能降甘露，以旌侯王能守道也。 人莫之令而自均。 王道无偏，故德泽平施，岂待命令。 始制有名，道至於此，始可制服有名之物。 有名之物，即山川可祭之神，林泉可征之士。 名亦既有。 如此，有名之物有封禅而必从伏林泉，而尽出朝见也。 夫亦将知止，夫此辈亦将知安於所止。 知止所以不殆。 殆，危也。 有名之物依於有道之君，而安於乐土，况百姓乎？ 譬道之在天下，犹川谷之与江海。 有道之主在於天下君臣道合，上恩下流，下情上达，如川谷之与江海通流也。 知人者智，智者不惑，故知人也。 自知者明。 明者见於未萌，故不履於非道。 胜人者有力，人所以胜人者，非有势力，即有膂力。 自胜者强。 能自修德以服人，殊强於有力者。 知足者富，若足於一瓢，则富於万国。 强行者有志。 行事始终如一，是有志节矣。 不失其所者久人而无常，必不能久行其道。 死而不亡者寿。 人能行道以利天下，所垂法则制度皆生於神识机智，一成之后，万古传之，是身死形谢而神长存，故曰寿也。 大道泛兮，其可左右。 大道泛泛兮，不击於一方，而云可左可右者，略举两端，明备万物。 万物恃之以生而不辞，生育之功成，亦不名我有。 爱养万物而不为主。 主则非忘功也。 常无欲，可名於小； 世人之无欲者，赤子也。 而道於物无欲，可是如赤子之小者乎？ 万物归之而不为主，可名於大。 万物悉归於道，道又不与为主，可是傲然为大，不顾於物者耶？ 是以圣人终不为大，圣人法道，法於为小，不法於为大者，恐失谦也。 故能成其大。 本无为大之心，翻成远大之业。 执大象，天下往，大象，道也。 未有一物不因道而为形象，若执此道以临天下，民无不归往也。 往而不害，安平泰。 既归之，当安之。 非清平之中，泰然舒息不可也。 乐与饵，过客止。

「Not Dao is early failure.
To know what is contrary to Dao,
And be able to stop early—this is good.

**Stopping** is **cessation**.
The **good general** who loves war
Is an **omen of misfortune**—*good*, meaning fondness.
War is the **instrument of harm**,
And fondness of war is not **virtue**.
**Things** may be evil,
Thus the **Daoist** does not dwell there.
All **things** cherish life and abhor death,
And if a realm loves war,
Even common **things** will detest it—
How much more so the **Daoist scholar**,
Who would dare to reside in such a realm?

A **gentleman** in **peace** holds the **left** in esteem,
For he embodies **仁 (rén)** to nurture others,
And in **peace**, he must occupy the **position of life’s flourishing**.
In war, he holds the **right** in esteem.
The **commander of war** takes killing as his purpose,
Thus his use must be **aligned with the path of destruction**—
War is an **omen of misfortune**,
Not the **instrument** of a **gentleman**.
A **gentleman**’s **instrument** is **cultural virtue (文德)**,
Not **weapons of violence (干戈)**.
When he **must** use it,
Though not his own **instrument**,
It is **not obtained otherwise**.

**Serenity and simplicity** are supreme.
The **flavor** of his use is **not** in **victory**,
For **victory** is **not** **beautiful**—
He values **serenity and simplicity** above all,
Thus **victory** is **not** **beautiful**.
But those who find it **beautiful**,
Rejoice in killing—*love*, meaning fondness.
If one takes **victory** as **beautiful**,
Then he is **fond of killing**—
He who rejoices in killing
Cannot fulfill his **aspirations** in the world.
All detest death—
Who would willingly **submit** to it?
Thus **auspicious matters** are **esteemed on the left**,
**Inauspicious matters** on the **right**.
Each follows its **kind**.

The **general of the left** dwells on the **left**,
Though he is the **official of killing**,
He lacks the **authority to kill**.
The **general of the right** dwells on the **right**,
Specializing in **campaigns and conquests**.
*Speaking* of **funeral rites**,
He is placed **near the coffin**.
Killing many,
He **lamented and wept**—
The **gentleman** as **general** would say:
*"Truly, I lack **virtue**,
The people have **no guilt**—
In one day, I slaughter and wound them,
Nearly driving them to **death**."*
Thus, **speaking of war**,
His **tears followed**—
The **victory** of war was **treated as funeral rites**.
Placing him in that position,
He need not **wear its garments**,
But **first**, to **align with its killing qi**,
And **second**, to **restrain the heart** of the **warlord**.

**Dao** is **always nameless**—
Now I name it **Dao**,
This is **forcing a name**.
Though **primordial simplicity (朴)** is small,
It is **such that one cannot see it**.
The world **dares not** to **submit** to it.
Holding **Dao** within,
He is still **worthy as a teacher** to the **sage-king**—
How much more so would he **dare to submit** to **Dao** as a **servant**?

If **marquis-kings (侯王)** could **guard** it,
The world would **voluntarily submit**.
*Submit*, meaning **to obey**—
If one **guards Dao** without forgetting,
Then none would **fail to submit** from afar.
**Heaven and Earth** unite,
And **descend sweet dew (甘露)**—
When **Heaven and Earth** exchange **harmony (泰)**,
They can **descend sweet dew**,
Thus **marquis-kings** who **guard Dao** are **signified**—
No one **commands** them,
Yet all **become equal**.

The **Way of the Sage** has **no bias**,
Thus his **virtue and grace** are **evenly bestowed**—
Why **await orders**?
At the **beginning of governance**, names are **established**,
Yet **Dao** reaches this point—
Only then can it **subdue and serve** the **named**.
The **named** are the **spirits of mountains and rivers**,
And the **scholars of forests and springs**.
Names are **already established**.
Thus, when **named spirits** are **enshrined**,
They **must submit** to **funeral rites**,
And **scholars of forests and springs**,
Though **exhausted from their labors**,
Will **all emerge** to **pay respects**.

He who **knows how to stop** will **not** be **endangered**—
*Endangered*, meaning **in peril**.
The **named** rely on the **Daoist ruler**,
And **find peace** in **auspicious lands**—
How much more so the **common folk**?

**Dao** in the world
Is like **streams and valleys** to the **great rivers and seas**.
The **Daoist ruler** in the **world**,
When **ruler and subject align with Dao**,
**Superior grace flows downward**,
**Inferior emotions reach upward**,
Like **streams and valleys** flowing into the **great rivers and seas**.

He who **knows others** is **wise**—
The **wise** are **not confused**,
Thus he **knows others**.
He who **knows himself** is **clear**—
The **clear** see **before things manifest**,
Thus he **does not tread upon what is contrary to Dao**.

He who **overcomes others** has **strength**—
Others **overcome others** by **power or might**,
But he who **overcomes himself** is **powerful**.
He who can **cultivate virtue** to **subdue others**
Is **far stronger** than those with mere **strength**.

He who **knows contentment** is **rich**—
If one is **content with a single gourd**,
Then he is **rich beyond all realms**.
He who **pursues strength** has **aspiration**—
To **begin and complete** matters **unwaveringly**
Is to have **aspiration and integrity**.
He who **does not lose his place** endures **long**—
Yet **without constancy**,
He cannot **long endure his Dao**.

He who **dies yet does not perish** is **long-lived**—
If a man **practices Dao** to **benefit the world**,
The **laws and institutions** he **leaves behind**
Emerge from **divine insight and wisdom**,
Once **established**, they **last eternally**—
This is **his body decaying** yet **his spirit enduring**,
Thus he is **long-lived**.

The **Great Dao** is **vast and boundless**—
It is **not confined to one side**,
Yet I say it is **left or right**—
This is **briefly illustrating two extremes**,
To **make clear** the **completeness of all things**.
All **things depend on it** to **flourish**,
Yet it **does not refuse**—
When **nurturing all things** is complete,
It **does not claim ownership**.
It **loves and nourishes** all **things** yet **does not rule** them.
To **rule** would be **not forgetting its deeds**.

**Always without desire**,
It can be **named small**—
The **desireless** of the world
Are **innocent children**.
But **Dao** in **things** has **no desire**,
Is it **as small as innocent children**?
All **things return** to it yet it **does not rule**—
Is it **as great as this**,
Yet **unconcerned with things**?

Thus, the **sage** never **claims greatness**—
The **sage** follows **Dao**,
And **follows the small**,
Not **following the great**,
For fear of **losing humility**.
Thus he **can achieve the greatest**.
Without the **heart to claim greatness**,
His **deeds become vast and enduring**.
Holding the **great image (大象)**—
The world **comes toward** it—
*The great image*, meaning **Dao**.
No **thing** exists that **does not**,
Through **Dao**, take **form and substance**—
If he **holds this Dao** to **face the world**,
The people **will not fail to come toward** it.

**Coming toward** yet **doing no harm**,
**Peace and ease prevail**.
Once they **have come toward** it,
They **must be settled**—
Not in **order and tranquility** alone,
But in **harmonious ease and repose**—
**Joy and bait**,
For **passing travelers** to **rest**.

chunks.original_text: 乐，音乐也。 饵，饮食也。 夫音乐饮食，人之所欲，岂有过之而不留止者乎？ 道之出口，淡乎其无味。 过客所以留止者，以其有阅目实腹之物也。 此大象之道，将出於口，以告於人，则淡之其无可味，如何使人慕之？ 且人性恶多事，好无为，道性无为，故人欲之矣。 视之不足见，听之不足闻，用之不可既。 既，尽也。 虽视听不足得其形声，必能用之，亦无穷尽。 将欲歙之，必固张之； 将欲弱之，必固强之； 将欲废之，必固兴之，将欲 夺之，必固与之。 是谓微明。 此四者，兆之初起，可谓之微，便能固其源而绝之萌也。 柔弱胜刚强，夫祸之始生柔弱也，终至茂盛刚强也。 将欲除之於柔弱之时，则全胜於刚强之日。 鱼不可脱於渊，鱼若脱手而入於渊，则不可得而制也。 国之利器，不可以示人。 利器者，机事也。 凡事机微之时，则能制之，不使至其强大，此实理身理国之要道也，必不得示诸小人。 若机落小人之手，则何异夫鱼之入渊乎？ 道常无为，而无不为，为而无心，故能无所不为也。 侯王若能守，万物将自化。 不失无为，则无不化。 化而欲作，吾将镇之以无名之朴。 无名之朴者，无为之本也。 夫无为也，则无迹，当何名之？ 君执此以镇人，人孰敢妄动者也？ 无名之朴，亦将不欲。 兼忘守道之心，乃合自然之素。 不欲以静，天下将自正。 夫有心於静者，则无时而静也。 今放之於自得，我无一物於胸中，然后君臣上下各正性命。 道德真经新注卷之二竟 道德真经新注卷之三
chunks.translated_text:
**Music is melody.**
**Bait is sustenance.**
What man desires—music and food—
Who, passing by, would not pause to rest?
**Dao**, when spoken, is bland, without taste.
Yet travelers linger because of sights to see,
And food to fill their bellies.
If this **great image (Dao)** were to emerge from the mouth,
To teach the people—bland, without savor—
How could one make them yearn for it?

Moreover, human nature is prone to excess,
Yet craves **non-action**.
**Dao** itself is **non-action**—
Thus men desire it.
To gaze upon it is insufficient to perceive its form,
To listen is insufficient to hear its sound,
Yet to employ it is inexhaustible.
*Inexhaustible*—meaning complete.
Though sight and hearing fail to grasp its shape and voice,
If one uses it, its power is boundless.
**To contract it**, one must first expand it;
**To weaken it**, one must first strengthen it;
**To discard it**, one must first establish it;
**To take it away**, one must first bestow it.
This is called **subtle clarity**.

These four principles—
At their nascent stage, may be called **subtle**,
Yet they can solidify the source
And sever the sprouts before they rise.

**Softness overcomes hardness**—
For what begins as frail and weak
Eventually flourishes into strength and vigor.
If one seeks to remove it in its tender state,
Victory is assured over its hardened form.

**Fish cannot be caught from the depths**—
If the fish slips from the hand and plunges into the deep,
It cannot be controlled.
**A nation’s sharpest tools**
Should not be displayed to the people.
*Sharp tools*—meaning **strategic schemes**.
When matters are in their embryonic stage,
They can be guided—
Not allowed to reach full strength.
This is the true principle for governing self and state,
And must never be revealed to the unworthy.
If such schemes fall into the hands of the unprincipled,
What difference is there from the fish slipping into the deep?

**Dao** acts without action,
Yet nothing remains undone.
It acts without intention—
Thus it accomplishes all things.

If lords and kings could uphold it,
All things would transform of their own accord.
If **non-action** is not abandoned,
Then nothing remains untransformed.
When transformation stirs,
I shall govern it with the **Uncarved Block of the Nameless**.
*The Uncarved Block of the Nameless*—
The foundation of **non-action**.
**Non-action** leaves no trace—
What name could it bear?
If the ruler holds this to govern the people,
Who would dare move recklessly?
The **Uncarved Block of the Nameless** also
Shall not desire.
When the mind of guarding **Dao** is forgotten,
One aligns with the original simplicity of nature.
**Non-desire**, through stillness,
And the world will self-correct.
He who seeks stillness with intent
Will never attain it.
Now, set free into natural ease,
With nothing in the breast—
Then ruler and subject, high and low,
Each return to their true nature.

*End of New Commentary on the Dao De Jing, Volume Two*
*Beginning of New Commentary on the Dao De Jing, Volume Three*

chunks.original_text: 李约注 德经上 凡四十一章 上德不德，人不见其迹，则谓之不德。 是以有德； 物不改其朴，然后知有德。 下德不失德，慕前王之美，恭守而不坠。 是以无德。 物性稍移，是知无德。 上德无为而无以为，不为而得。 下德为之而有以为。 为而得也。 上仁为之始化道而为仁也。 而无以为，虽为之而无心。 上义为之始化道而为义。 而有以为。 专於制断。 上礼为之始化道而为礼。 而莫之应，则攘臂而仍之。 赠答失所，故有斯怒。 故失道而后德，上德合道，故云失道。 下德次之，此所以有德、有仁、有义、有礼。 既失上德，则下德为继之。 失德而后仁，下德有失、仁教嗣兴。 失仁而后义，仁教又替，义方遂行。 失义而后礼。 是非合宜，已谢於时，拜跪玉帛； 将盛於世。 夫礼者，忠信之薄而乱之首。 乱者，君不君，臣不臣，父不父，，子不子也。 忠信者，道德也。 若以礼比於道德，诚为衰薄。 用救於乱，则舍礼何从。 前识者，是先识礼人也。 道之华礼可以悦人之目，是谓道花也。 古花字，今华字是也。 而愚之始。 适可为愚者，检逸之初也。 是以大丈夫大丈夫者，丈夫雄者也。 丈夫之雄性，必方直不徇浮俗，故《昌言》云：若大丈夫，则必行道德，不敦末礼也。 处其厚不处其薄，必致身於道德，不置身於衰薄。 居其实不居其华，实如草木之实，能实人之腹，故居之。 花如草木之华，徒阅人之目，故不居也。 故去彼取此。 去花而取实。 昔之得一者，在下文也。 天得一以清，地得一以宁，谷得一以盈，神得一以灵，万物得一以生，侯王得一以为天下贞。 自天地已降至于侯王，所以能清等，皆得道之一，故令侯王正身以正於人，故云天下贞。 贞，正也。 其致之，既知得道，其致之如是，岂得失之哉？ 天无以清将恐裂，地无以宁将恐发，谷无以盈将恐竭，神无以灵将恐歇，万物无以生将恐灭，侯王无以贵高将恐蹙。 灵，颠覆也。 若得之而不守，故其患若此也。 故贵以贱为本，王贵也，民贱也，王以民为本，故有民则有王也。 高以下为基。 九仞之山，一篑之基，若为基不固，山必颓矣。 将存其贵，不安於民，则民散而王蹶矣。 是以侯王自谓孤寡不谷，此其以贱为本耶？ 非乎？ 孤，子无父也。 寡，妇无夫也。 不谷，生无养也。 此三者，人之所恶，而侯王称之，岂非以贱为本耶？ 非乎者，言正是以贱为本也。 故致数舆无舆，就舆数之，但得轮辕等众材也。 则就王数之，但得卿士等兆民也。 若散众材，则无成舆之日； 不安兆民，焉有为王之时？ 不欲碌碌如玉，落落如石。 碌碌，贵貌也。 落落，贱貌也。 玉虽贵，因石而生； 王虽尊，因民而有。 以此不欲如玉，欲如石者，敦本故也。 反者道之动，道体寂今也，动反也，所以反者为物性之有刚也，故设权刚以待之，亦冀反其寂也。 弱者道之用。 柔弱者，道之常用。 物皆知之，今再明者？ 恐因权刚之义，便谓道用合然矣。 天下万物生於有，万物皆自有形天地而生也。 有生於无。 即有形天地自道而生。 道，无也。 上士闻道，勤而行之； 闻之而悟，遂勤行而反本。 中士闻道，若存若亡； 闻之而疑，犹可教也，使知道也。 下士闻道，大笑之，闻之而惑，故大笑，则不可使白方也。

「Li Yue’s Annotation: *Dao De Jing*, Upper Section

**Chapter Forty-One:**

The **virtue/power** of the Highest **Dao/Way** does not cling to **virtue/power**,
Yet men do not see its trace—
Then they call it *not* **virtue/power**.

Thus, it is indeed **virtue/power**:
Things do not alter their **Uncarved Block**—
Only then does one know it as **virtue/power**.

The **virtue/power** of the Lowest **Dao/Way** does not abandon **virtue/power**,
Admiring the beauty of former kings,
Reverently guarding it without decline.
Thus, it is *not* **virtue/power**.

When the nature of things slightly shifts,
One knows it as *not* **virtue/power**.

The **virtue/power** of the Highest **Dao/Way** acts without action yet nothing is left undone,
Does without doing yet achieves.
The **virtue/power** of the Lowest **Dao/Way** acts with doing yet leaves nothing undone,
Does with doing yet achieves.

The **virtue/power** of the Highest Benevolence
Begins by transforming **Dao/Way** into benevolence,
Yet nothing is left undone—
Though it acts, its mind remains undisturbed.

The **virtue/power** of the Highest Righteousness
Begins by transforming **Dao/Way** into righteousness,
Yet leaves nothing undone—
Focusing solely on judgment and restraint.

The **virtue/power** of the Highest Propriety
Begins by transforming **Dao/Way** into propriety,
Yet none respond—
Then they roll up their sleeves and force it upon them.
Gifts and replies are misplaced,
Thus arises this anger.
Hence, **virtue/power** is lost before **Dao/Way** is lost—
The Highest **Dao/Way** aligns with **Dao/Way**, hence the saying *loses **Dao/Way***.
The **virtue/power** of the Lowest **Dao/Way** follows next,
This is why there is **virtue/power**, benevolence, righteousness, and propriety.
Having lost the Highest **virtue/power**,
The Lowest **virtue/power** takes its place.

**Virtue/power** is lost before benevolence—
The Lowest **virtue/power** has its flaws,
Thus teachings of benevolence arise.
Benevolence is lost before righteousness—
Teachings of benevolence decline,
Thus righteousness prevails.
Righteousness is lost before propriety—
Right and wrong, fitting and improper,
Already fading in time,
Bow and kneel, jade and silk,
Flourish in the world.
For propriety is but the thinnest veneer of loyalty and trust,
And the beginning of chaos.
Chaos is when rulers are not rulers,
Subjects are not subjects,
Fathers are not fathers,
Sons are not sons.
Loyalty and trust are **virtue/power** and **Dao/Way**.
If propriety is compared to **virtue/power** and **Dao/Way**,
It is indeed decayed and thin.
Yet to save from chaos,
Where else would one turn but propriety?
Those who foresaw this knew that propriety would please the eyes of the people—
This is called the *flower of **Dao/Way***.
In ancient times, *flower* was written; now *ornament* is used instead.
Yet it is the beginning of foolishness.
If it is suitable for the foolish,
It is the first sign of extravagance.
Thus, a true **man of **Dao/Way****—
A **man of **Dao/Way**** is one of strong character.
The strong character of a **man of **Dao/Way****
Must be square and upright, not yielding to superficial trends,
Hence the *Changyan* says:
*A true **man of **Dao/Way****, must practice **virtue/power** and **Dao/Way**,
Not indulge in superficial propriety.*
Dwelling in its depth, not in its shallowness,
He must commit himself to **virtue/power** and **Dao/Way**,
Not place himself in decayed thinness.
Residing in substance, not in ornament—
Substance like the fruit of grass and trees,
Filling the stomach of men,
Thus it is dwelt upon.
Ornament like the flowers of grass and trees,
Merely pleasing to the eye,
Thus it is not dwelt upon.
Hence, he discards that and takes this—
Discarding ornament, taking substance.
The *ancient ones who attained **Oneness*** are found in the lower text.

Heaven attains **Oneness** and finds clarity,
Earth attains **Oneness** and finds tranquility,
The valleys attain **Oneness** and fill,
The **spirit** attains **Oneness** and becomes luminous,
All things attain **Oneness** and live,
Noble kings attain **Oneness** to rule the world with rectitude.
From Heaven and Earth descending to noble kings,
What enables them to be clear and tranquil,
Is attaining **Oneness** from **Dao/Way**,
Hence the noble kings rectify themselves to rectify the people,
Thus the world is ruled with rectitude.
*Rectitude* means *correctness*.
Their attainment is as follows:
Having known **Dao/Way**,
Their attainment is thus—
How could they lose it?

Heaven without clarity would fear collapse,
Earth without tranquility would fear upheaval,
The valleys without fullness would fear exhaustion,
The **spirit** without luminosity would fear cessation,
All things without life would fear annihilation,
Noble kings without nobility would fear decline.
*Cessation* means *overturned*.
If one attains it yet does not guard it,
Thus arise these calamities.

Hence, nobility takes humility as its foundation,
Kings are noble, the people are humble,
Kings take the people as their foundation,
Thus there are people, there are kings.
Highness takes lowliness as its base.
A mountain nine *zhang* high,
A single basketful as its base—
If the base is not firm,
The mountain will topple.
To preserve nobility,
Not resting securely upon the people,
Then the people scatter and the kings decline.
Thus, noble kings call themselves *lonely, childless, without grain*—
Is this not taking humility as their foundation?
No, it is not.
*Lonely* means *child without father*,
*Childless* means *woman without husband*,
*Without grain* means *life without sustenance*.
These three are what men detest,
Yet noble kings claim them—
Is this not taking humility as their foundation?
No, it is not—
It is saying that correctness is taking humility as the foundation.

Hence, when attaining the **Dao/Way** of a chariot,
One seeks the **Dao/Way** of a chariot—
Only the wheels and axles and all the materials are obtained.
Then, when attaining the **Dao/Way** of a king,
One seeks the **Dao/Way** of a king—
Only the ministers and the common people are obtained.
If one scatters the materials,
There will be no day of making a chariot;
If one does not rest securely upon the people,
How could there be a time for ruling as a king?

Do not desire to be smooth and polished like jade,
Nor rough and unrefined like stone.
*Smooth and polished* is the appearance of nobility,
*Rough and unrefined* is the appearance of humility.
Though jade is noble,
It grows from stone;
Though kings are exalted,
They depend upon the people.
Thus, not desiring to be like jade,
Desiring to be like stone,
Is to cherish the foundation.
*Reversion* is the movement of **Dao/Way**,
**Dao/Way**’s essence is stillness—
Movement is reversion,
The reason for reversion is the rigid nature of things,
Hence setting forth the rigid to meet it,
Also hoping to reverse its stillness.

Softness is the application of **Dao/Way**.
The soft and weak are the constant use of **Dao/Way**.
All things know this,
Yet it is made clear again—
For fear that, due to the meaning of *setting forth the rigid*,
One would say that the application of **Dao/Way** is naturally so.

All things under Heaven are born from *having*,
All things are born from the forms of Heaven and Earth.
*Having* is born from *non-having*.
That is, the forms of Heaven and Earth are born from **Dao/Way**.
**Dao/Way** is *non-having*.

The Superior **man of **Dao/Way**** hears **Dao/Way**,
Diligently practices it;
Hearing it and understanding,
He diligently practices and returns to the foundation.

The Middle **man of **Dao/Way**** hears **Dao/Way**,
As if it exists, as if it does not;
Hearing it and doubting,
It is still teachable—
To make him know **Dao/Way**.

The Inferior **man of **Dao/Way**** hears **Dao/Way**,
And laughs greatly—
Hearing it and being confused,
Thus he laughs greatly,
Then one cannot make him white as snow.»

chunks.original_text: 不笑不足以为道。 道为下士入耳之音，则不足为贵。 建言有之：建，立也。 立言明中下二士疑其大笑之由。 明道若昧，行昭而用晦也。 进道若退，内勤而外怠也。 夷道若颜，颣，丝之不匀者。 履平而若险。 上德若谷，无心而善应也。 大白若辱，性洁而迹污也。 广德若不足，道不形於色也。 建德若偷，才不露於外也。 质真若渝，至绝反如滥也。 大方无隅，无岸谷可见也。 大器晚成，不日求以得也。 大音希声，希，无也。 无声乐也。 大象无形，无状之状。 道隐无名。 自建言已下，皆是大道隐於无名也，故上士洞悟而勤行，中士疑而进退，下士惑而大笑，识此之由。 夫唯道，善贷且成。 道不以三士不同，亦均贷和气，皆使生成。 而勤行者独还和於道中，而疑笑者并乾没於元气也。 道生一，谓应感而生一气也。 一生二，一始生阴气，二始生阳气也。 二生三，三者，阴阳相感通而生和气也。 三生万物。 和气聚而生万物也。 万物负阴而抱阳，冲气以为和。 凡物皮质外周曰负阴。 皮质，阴气为也。 骨髓内充曰抱阳。 骨体，阳气为也。 道气柔弱，贯通其间而和之。 人之所恶，唯孤寡不谷，而王公以为称。 王公之和气柔弱，为万物本，故能以不祥为称，是以为天下君。 故物或损之而益，称不祥，诚自损也，物无不宾，非益而何？ 或益之而损。 恃贵者，己自益也，民皆离心，非损何也？ 人之所教，亦我义教之。 人欲立教教人者，亦当以我柔弱之义教之，则服膺者莫不归於性命之城。 强梁者，不得其死。 君强暴则失臣不之心，覆亡无日。 人强梁则为众所加，颠踬可待。 吾将以为教父。 父，人之先也。 吾以柔弱之义为众教之先。 天下之至柔，驰骋天下之至坚。 夫和气者，天下至柔之物也。 若人驰骋之，则化为天下至坚之物。 无有入於无间，将欲复和气而为至柔者，但能无有驰骋之志，明和气自入於无间之心，化为至柔之物也。 吾是以知无为之有益。 老子云； 我见无为驰骋者，则能令和气长在於心，柔弱而长生也，所以知无为有益於人也。 不言之教，无为之益，天下希及之。 不言於人，无为於己，其为益也，天下罕能及此。 名与身孰亲？ 名可舍，身不可舍，则何者疏也？ 身与货孰多？ 货失而可求，身亡而难得，则何者少也？ 得与亡孰病？ 得则亡身，亡则全真，则何者为利？ 故甚爱必大费，欲过於分，所损亦重。 多藏必厚亡。 积而不散，十九而死。 知足不辱，足於心则常荣。 知止不殆，止於分则常安。 可以长久。 必无中道而夭。 大成若缺，德全者，故貌如不足也。 其用不弊。 其应物也，无所不能也。 大盈若冲，内实者，故外如虚也。 其用不穷。 至於济众未尝竭也。 大直若屈，含垢而不申也。 大巧若拙，不矜其能。 大辩若讷。 似不能言。 躁胜寒，物极则反，故夏至则一阴生乎其中矣。 静胜热，否极则泰，故冬至则一阳生乎其中矣。 清静为天下正。 正者，躁静之中，则二月八月也。 故大成以下至于大辩，皆适躁静之中，得天下之正者也。 天下有道，却走马以粪。 有道之主嗣庸君之后，则必拨乱反正，偃武修文，是以前王所征之马走在道路，今我不用，却使还家粪理农业。 天下无道，戎马生於郊。 无道之君继清平之后，恃以府藏充实，遂好攻战，侵人土地，所以士不解鞍，长在境上。
chunks.translated_text:
The **Dao/Way** is not to be taken lightly—
For when it enters the ears of the Inferior **man of Dao/Way** as mere sound,
It is not worthy of esteem.

Let me establish this teaching:
*"Establish"* means to clarify.
Clarify the doubts of the Middle and Inferior **men of Dao/Way**,
Why they laugh in derision.

The **Dao/Way** is bright yet hidden in practice,
Illuminated in deed yet concealed in application.
Advancing the **Dao/Way** seems like retreat—
Within, diligent; without, appearing idle.
Making the **Dao/Way** plain seems like disorder—
Like uneven silk, rough to the touch.
Treading the level ground as if on perilous heights.
**Virtue/power** most exalted resembles a valley—
Without contrivance, yet responsive in all things.
Great whiteness seems like shame—
Pure in nature, yet stained in appearance.
Ample **virtue/power** appears insufficient—
The **Dao/Way** does not manifest in form.
Established **virtue/power** seems like theft—
Talent concealed, not displayed.
True substance seems corrupted—
The most absolute becomes like excess.
The greatest square has no corners—
No edges or valleys are visible.
Great vessels take long to form—
Not sought daily and obtained.
Great music is without sound—
*"Hesitant"* means *nonexistent*.
Without sound, yet joyous.
Great images are formless—
The form of the formless.

From *"Establish this teaching"* onward,
All speak of the **Dao/Way** hidden in the nameless.
Thus, the Superior **man of Dao/Way** penetrates and practices with diligence,
The Middle **man of Dao/Way** doubts and hesitates,
The Inferior **man of Dao/Way** is confused and laughs—
Now you know the reason.

Only the **Dao/Way** is good at lending and completing.
The **Dao/Way** does not discriminate among the three **men of Dao/Way**,
But uniformly lends its harmonizing *qi*—
All things grow and are completed.
Yet those who practice diligently alone return to harmony with the **Dao/Way**,
While those who doubt and laugh both perish in the original *qi*.

The **Dao/Way** generates *Oneness*—
That is, it responds to stimuli and generates *One qi*.
*One* generates *Two*—
*One* first generates *yin qi*,
*Two* first generates *yang qi*.
*Two* generates *Three*—
*Three* is when *yin* and *yang* interact and generate harmonizing *qi*.
*Three* generates all things—
Harmonizing *qi* gathers and gives birth to all things.
All things carry *yin* externally and embrace *yang* internally,
Their clashing *qi* harmonizes.
Generally, the outer skin and texture are called *"carrying yin."*
Skin and texture are the work of *yin qi*.
The marrow and bones, filled within, are called *"embracing yang."*
Bone structure is the work of *yang qi*.
The **Dao/Way**’s *qi* is soft and weak,
Penetrating and harmonizing between them.

What people detest are the *Three Loneliness*—
The solitary, the widowed, the childless—
Yet kings and nobles take them as titles.
The kings and nobles’ harmonizing *qi* is soft and weak,
The root of all things,
Thus they can use what is unlucky as their title,
And so become rulers of the world.
Thus, some things are diminished yet benefit—
Calling it unlucky is truly self-diminishment,
For how could anything not submit?
Or benefit yet be diminished—
Those who rely on their noble status
Are themselves the benefactors,
Yet the people’s hearts turn away—
What else but loss could it be?

What people teach is also my teaching.
If one desires to establish teaching for others,
They must also teach with the principle of softness and weakness,
Then those who embrace it will all return to the city of nature and life.

The strong and violent do not meet a good end.
When a ruler is strong and tyrannical,
His ministers’ loyalty wanes, and ruin is imminent.
When a person is strong and violent,
They are overthrown by the many—
Their downfall is inevitable.
I will make this my teaching’s foundation.
*"Foundation"* means what comes first.
I make the principle of softness and weakness
The first teaching for the people.

The most soft under Heaven
Overcomes the most hard under Heaven.
For harmonizing *qi* is the most soft thing under Heaven.
If one rides it,
It transforms into the most hard thing under Heaven.
There is nothing that enters the unbroken—
If one wishes to restore harmonizing *qi* to its softness,
Simply abandon the intent to ride it,
Clarify the mind that harmonizing *qi* naturally enters the unbroken,
And it transforms into the most soft thing.

Thus I know the benefits of *wuwei*.
Laozi said:
*"I see those who ride *wuwei*—
They can make harmonizing *qi* dwell eternally in the heart,
Soft and weak, yet long-lived—
Thus I know *wuwei* benefits people."*

The teaching of silence,
The benefits of *wuwei*—
Few under Heaven can attain them.
To not speak to others,
To practice *wuwei* oneself—
Few under Heaven can do this.

Which is closer: name or body?
Name can be discarded, but body cannot—
Then which is more distant?
Which is more abundant: body or wealth?
Wealth lost can be sought, but life lost cannot be regained—
Then which is scarcer?
Which is more harmful: gain or loss?
Gain leads to losing the body,
Loss preserves the true self—
Then which is truly advantageous?

Thus excessive love brings great expenditure—
Desire beyond measure means great loss.
Hoarding leads to great ruin.
Accumulating without dispersing,
Nineteen out of twenty will die.
Knowing sufficiency brings no disgrace—
Sufficiency in the heart brings constant honor.
Knowing when to stop brings no peril—
Stopping at one’s measure brings constant peace.
This is how one endures long.

Great completion resembles deficiency—
Those with full **virtue/power** appear lacking.
Their use is unexhausted.
Their response to things is boundless.

Great fullness resembles emptiness—
Those internally real appear externally void.
Their use is inexhaustible.
Even in aiding the multitude, they are never depleted.

Great straightness resembles bending—
They endure filth without complaint.
Great skill resembles clumsiness—
They do not boast of their abilities.
Great eloquence resembles stammering—
Seeming unable to speak.

The restless overcomes the cold—
Things at their extreme reverse—
Thus at the summer solstice, *yin* begins to arise within it.
The tranquil overcomes the heat—
Misfortune at its peak becomes fortune—
Thus at the winter solstice, *yang* begins to arise within it.

Calmness and stillness are the norm for the world.
*"Norm"* means the balance between restlessness and tranquility—
Thus the second and eighth months.
Hence, from *"Great completion"* onward to *"Great eloquence,"*
All conform to the balance between restlessness and tranquility,
Attaining the world’s norm.

When the world follows the **Dao/Way**,
Warhorses are driven back to manure fields.
A **Dao/Way**-governed ruler succeeds a mediocre one,
And must rectify chaos and restore order,
Abandoning arms and cultivating culture—
Thus the warhorses formerly used in conquest
Are now unused and returned to their homes
To till the fields.

When the world lacks the **Dao/Way**,
Warhorses breed in the suburbs.
A ruler without the **Dao/Way** follows a peaceful era,
Relying on abundant treasuries,
And grows fond of warfare,
Seizing others’ lands—
Thus soldiers never dismount,
Ever stationed at the borders.

chunks.original_text: 罪莫大於可欲，於求物之中，尚有其数。 祸莫大於不知足，经於目者，辄无所舍。 咎莫甚於欲得。 见与不见，咸欲求之，则天下之物靡有孑遗，此皆无道之君所行之事。 故知足之足，知止於足，则土阶茅茨，未为不足。 常足矣。 不踰於分，贵安人，此有道之君也。 不出户，以知天下； 以身度之，天下可知。 不窥牖，以见天道。 法天而行，不必窥牖。 其出弥远，其知弥少。 不知民安在於无事，反为事以安之，则事出弥远，而民安弥少。 是以圣人不行而知，知民安由己已，但无事则民安矣，不必行於天下也。 不见而名，守道在位，则太阶自平，岂待窥牖见而明之？ 不为而成。 成此至理，由乎不为也。 向若为之，则无因及此也。 为学日益，为学者日益闻见也。 为道日损。 为道者日损云为也。 损之又损，一损尚浅，再损方深。 以至於无为。 损至於无损，乃游乎环中。 无为而无不为。 功成不宰，是无为。 生成万有，是无不为也。 取天下常以无事，无事，无为不顺人之事，　言与众同好恶，非自取便於身之事也。 及其有事，不足以取天下。 若取便身之事则烦人，人烦则离散，安可以取天下也？ 圣人无常心，如虚舟之泛然也。 以百姓心为心。 百姓所乐者，君为成之。 善者吾善之，不违其性。 不善者吾亦善之，德善。 圣人自善身，而恶者自化之为善矣，终不役物以从己也。 信者吾信之，不夺其志。 不信者吾亦信之，德信。 圣人自推诚於天下，而人自化之为信，非制之使为也。 圣人在天下，惵惵焉，圣人在天下常惵惵焉轸虑，虑一物之不安也。 为天下浑其心。 天下之民欲乎无事，故吾浑心同民之欲。 百姓皆注其耳目，百姓皆倾注耳目，以观听圣人从民之欲否。 圣人皆孩之。 圣人念而抚之如赤子，宁忍以事扰之。 出生入死，邪妄出於心则生，入则死。 生之徒十有三，死之徒十有三，内五藏，外八使，耳目鼻口手足及三漏，内外都十三之徒侣也。 八使驰於外，五藏纳於内，共陷人以至死。 若以无事，各清其司，则致人以全生也。 又云：五藏、五形、三田为十三，头及四肢为五形。 三田，《黄庭经》云：上丹田脑也，中丹田心脾之间，下丹田肾中气海也。 人之生动之死地，十有三。 人之求生誙誙然，咸投足於死地者，亦由十三诱之。
chunks.translated_text:
「Guilt is none greater than craving what is not right,
Within the pursuit of things, there are yet its limits.
Misfortune is none greater than not knowing contentment—
What lies before one’s eyes, one must not abandon.
Blame is none more severe than desiring to obtain.
Whether seen or unseen, all must be sought,
Then nothing in the world remains untaken—
These are the deeds of rulers without the **Dao/Way**.

Thus, the contentment of *knowing contentment*,
Knowing to stop at contentment,
Then earthen steps and thatched roofs
Are not yet deemed insufficient—
Ever content, one does not overstep one’s portion.
To cherish peace among the people,
This is the ruler with the **Dao/Way**.

Not stepping outside one’s door, yet knowing the world—
By measuring it with oneself, the world may be understood.
Not peering through the window, yet seeing the **Dao/Way**—
To act in accordance with Heaven, one need not peer through windows.
The farther one ventures, the less one knows.
The people’s peace lies in the absence of strife,
Yet one contrives strife to bring them peace—
Then strife grows ever more distant,
And the people’s peace ever more scarce.

Hence, the sage acts without knowing,
Knowing that the people’s peace rests in their own tranquility—
If there is no strife, the people are at peace,
No need to act upon the world.

The sage does not see yet names,
Guarding the **Dao/Way** in office—
Then the grand steps of governance naturally level,
Why await peering through windows to discern clarity?

The sage does not act yet accomplishes.
To perfect this supreme principle,
One must do nothing.
Had one acted otherwise,
This result would never have come to pass.

To study is to grow daily,
But those who study grow ever more aware.
To cultivate the **Dao/Way** is to diminish daily.
Those who cultivate the **Dao/Way** diminish their actions day by day.
Diminish again and again—
One diminishment is yet shallow,
Two diminishments, then deep.
Until one reaches *non-action*.
Diminish until there is no diminishment,
Then one wanders in the *Huan Zhong* [1].

Without action yet without failing to act—
To complete great deeds without taking credit is *non-action*.
To give rise to all things is without failing to act.
To take the world, one must first ensure its peace—
Peace means *non-action* does not go against the people’s will,
Nor does it take what benefits oneself alone.
If one takes what benefits oneself alone, it troubles the people,
And when the people are troubled, they scatter and disperse—
How then can one take the world?

The sage has no fixed heart,
Like a hollow boat drifting freely upon the waters.
He takes the hearts of the people as his own.
What the people delight in, the sage brings to fruition,
Not contradicting their nature.
Even what is not good, the sage transforms into good,
Through the power of virtue—
He never forces others to submit to his own will.

The trustworthy, I trust them,
Not thwarting their resolve.
The untrustworthy, I also trust them,
Through the power of virtue.
The sage extends sincerity to the world,
And the people naturally transform into trustworthiness—
Not by decree, but by their own accord.

The sage dwells in the world,
Ever mindful—
The sage, dwelling in the world,
Ever bears in mind the burdens of the people,
Lest any single thing bring them distress.
He blends his heart with the people’s desires.
The people all focus their ears and eyes,
All straining their ears and eyes,
To observe and listen whether the sage follows their desires.
The sage treats them as infants—
In thought and deed, he nurtures them as tender children,
Never bearing to disturb them with strife.

Life and death arise from the heart’s deceit—
Deceit in the heart gives rise to life,
While truth brings death.
Those who cling to life number thirteen,
Those who cling to death number thirteen.
Within, the five **zang** organs [2],
Without, the eight **fu** organs [3],
Eyes, ears, nose, mouth, hands, feet, and the three **lù** afflictions [4]—
Together, they lead all people to their deaths.

The eight **fu** organs race outward,
The five **zang** organs receive inward,
Both conspire to drag people to their deaths.
If one ensures peace—
Each cleanses its own domain,
Then one brings people to full life.

Again it is said:
The five **zang** organs, five **xíng** forms [5], and three **dàn** fields [6] make thirteen.
The head and the four limbs are the five **xíng** forms.
The three **dàn** fields, as the *Huángtíng Jīng* [7] states:
The upper **dàn** field is the brain,
The middle **dàn** field lies between the heart and spleen,
The lower **dàn** field is the **qì** sea within the kidneys.
The thirteen paths that lead to life or death—
Those who seek life, ever restless,
All fall into the path of death,
Also through the thirteen that deceive them.»

---
[1] *Huan Zhong* (环中) – The "circular center" or "middle void," a Daoist concept of balance and harmony beyond extremes.
[2] *Zang* (五藏) – The five solid organs: heart, liver, spleen, lungs, kidneys.
[3] *Fu* (八使) – The eight hollow organs: gallbladder, stomach, small intestine, large intestine, bladder, triple burner, lungs (shared with *zang*), and heart (shared with *zang*).
[4] *Lù* (三漏) – The "three leaks" or defilements: desire, aversion, and delusion.
[5] *Xíng* (五形) – The five physical forms: head, arms, legs, and torso.
[6] *Dàn* (三田) – The "three fields" or energy centers in Daoist physiology.
[7] *Huángtíng Jīng* (黄庭经) – A Daoist alchemical text, "Scripture of the Yellow Court."

chunks.original_text: 夫何故？ 问往死地之由。 以其生生之厚。 对曰盖缘过求世物，充养太丰，是使十三之徒杀人得便也。 盖闻善摄生者，摄，养也。 善养生者，则约彼十三於清静之中，放此一身於忘形之地。 陆行不遇兕虎，兕虎皆猛兽，能以爪角伤人，我无害物之心，故不值此类。 入军不被甲兵，兵能残人，甲可御害，我无斗志，故不假带此器。 兕无所投其角，虎无所措其爪，兵无所容其刃。 若专以害物为心，则虽蜂趸至微，不能不以毒中人也，而况虎兕等乎？ 苟无伤物之志，虽被猛兽利兵，又何以加我乎？ 又云：兕虎甲兵比类身中贪邪也，言清静无为则祸患无因而入，疾病无由而生也。 夫何故？ 问免死之由。
chunks.translated_text:
Why is this so?
Asking the cause of falling into the realm of death.
It is because of the excess of life’s nourishment.
The reply: It is due to overindulgence in worldly things,
to overfeeding and overindulgence—
thus the thirteen [deceivers] find opportunity to kill.

It is said that those who excel in preserving life—
*preserving* meaning *nourishing*—
those who excel in nourishing life
restrain the thirteen within the realm of purity and stillness,
and abandon this body in the place of formlessness.

When walking on land, one does not encounter rhinoceros or tigers—
rhinoceros and tigers are fierce beasts,
capable of harming with claw and horn,
yet without the intent to harm others,
one avoids such encounters.

Entering battlefields, one is not struck by weapons or armor—
weapons can maim, armor can defend,
yet without the will to fight,
one does not need to bear such implements.

The rhinoceros has no place to thrust its horn,
the tiger no place to strike with its claw,
the blade no place to find its edge.
If one’s heart is fixed on harming others,
even the smallest insect—
a wasp or hornet—
cannot fail to sting,
much less tigers and rhinoceros!

If one harbors no intent to harm,
even when confronted by fierce beasts or sharp weapons,
how could they harm you?

It is further said:
Rhinoceros, tigers, weapons, and armor
are likened to the evils within the body—
to say that in purity and non-action,
calamity has no cause to enter,
and sickness no means to arise.

Why is this so?
Asking the reason for avoiding death.

chunks.original_text: 以其无死地。 十三之徒为清静所排，不令引五贼三尸入於心地，则无死地可入也。 若失清静於毫厘，则五贼三尸间隙而进，得措其角爪刃矣。 道生之，始贷气也。 德畜之，遂含育也。 物形之，质方具也。 势成之，四时更生，物遂化就。 是以万物莫不尊道而贵德。 物虽至愚，未有不知父母而尊贵之。 道之尊，德之贵，夫莫之爵而常自然。 世人之尊贵者，为受帝王锡命也。 而道德不假於此，自有生成之功，故为物所尊贵也。 故道生之畜之，长之育之，成之熟之，养之覆之。 有如此力，故不假爵命也。 生而不有，有则收其仁也。 为而不恃恃则居其功也。 是谓玄德。 可谓阴德。 天下有始，始，本也，万物资之所以生。 以为天下母。 母，养也，万物由之所以成。 既知其母，又知其子； 以知道之母，物为之子明矣。 既知其子，复守其母，既知子由生，则知守母以存其子。 没身不殆。 道既扶之，何危之有？ 塞其兑； 缄无默之目也。 闭其门，杜多言之口也。 终身不勤。 遂形逸而神王。 开其兑，济其事，民之於欲也甚勤，以道防间，犹恐其逸，况开济者乎？ 终身不救。 祸已成矣，不可匡救。 见小曰明，造形则悟。 守柔曰强积弱所致也。 用其光，复归其明。 观守母存子之法，得法则收视而守中。 见小守柔，是其法也。 无遗身殃，能不以祸自偿。 是谓袭常。 可谓潜至长生之道。 使我介然有知，行於大道，介，孤介也。 疾时不行正道之道，故曰若使我孤介之士有知天下之分，则使直道大行於天下。 唯施是畏。 唯，独也。 独施正直，是畏众邪？ 大道甚夷，实君臣之坦途也。 而人好径。 以时人好邪道，我权轻不能制。 朝甚除，盛修饰也。 田甚芜，夺民时也。 仓甚虚，民乏食也。 服文彩，君财丰也。 带利剑，好戎装也。 默饮食，祆珍羞也。 财货有余，厚歙得也。 是谓盗夸，不义而得，非盗而何，曾无作色，乃更夸示。 非道也哉。 也哉者，叹辞也。 盗已非道，况更矜夸？ 诚如斯人，实堪兴叹。 善建者不拔，善建国立身者必以德，以德者则身不危而国不拔。 拔，倾拔也。 善抱者不脱，脱，失也。 夫建国者抱民，立身者抱神，若皆以德，则无脱失也。 子孙祭杞不辍。 辍，止也。 善以德建国抱民者，则子孙繁昌，世世祭杞不辍止时也。 修之於身，其德乃真； 以德修身，诸伪咸尽。 修之於家，其德乃有余； 以德修家，庆流后嗣。 修之於乡，其德乃长； 以德修乡，日益远大。 修之於国，其德乃丰； 以德修国，君民充实。 修之於天下，其德乃普。 以德修於天下，则比屋可封，化被异域，故梯山航海而朝贡焉。 故以身观身，以家观家，以乡观乡，以国观国，以天下观天下。 但对观之，则兴亡可见。 吾何以知天下之然？ 以此。 以上事所以知之也。
chunks.translated_text:
The place where death cannot enter is because of its non-existence.

The thirteen cohorts are repelled by purity and non-action,
preventing the Five Evils and Three Corpses from entering the heart.
Thus, there is no place for death to take root.

If one loses purity even by a hair’s breadth,
the Five Evils and Three Corpses seize the opportunity to advance,
and their horns, claws, and blades find purchase.

The Way gives birth to it—
the initial loan of *qi*.
Virtue nurtures it—
the gradual containment and sustenance.
Things shape it—
the substance and form take full form.
Circumstance completes it—
the four seasons cycle, and things transform accordingly.
Thus, all things do not fail to revere the Way and honor virtue.

Even the most foolish creature knows not to dishonor its parents and fails to revere them.
The Way’s exaltation, virtue’s nobility—
none bestow them, yet they arise naturally.

What mortals revere and honor are those who receive imperial mandate.
But the Way and virtue require no such conferral;
they possess the inherent function of generation,
and thus are revered and honored by all things.

Therefore, the Way gives birth, nurtures, lengthens, and matures it,
completes and ripens it, nourishes and shelters it.
With such power, it needs no titles or commands.

It gives birth yet does not possess—
possession would exhaust its benevolence.
It acts yet does not rely—
reliance would claim its merit.
This is called the Mysterious Virtue.
It may be called Hidden Benevolence.

The world has a beginning—
the beginning is the root,
the source from which all things derive their birth.
It is the Mother of the world.
The Mother is nourishment,
the means by which all things achieve completion.
Having known the Mother, one knows the child;
knowing the Way as Mother, the child is clearly the things.
Having known the child, one returns to guard the Mother—
knowing the child arises from birth,
one knows to guard the Mother to preserve the child.
Thus, one avoids peril to the end of life.
The Way upholds it—
what danger could there be?

Seal the *yue* orifice;
close the eyes to idle speech.
Shut the gate;
seal the mouth that speaks much.
Thus, one lives a life without toil,
and the form rests while the spirit reigns supreme.

Open the *yue* orifice, aid its affairs—
the people’s desires are already excessive;
with the Way to guard the gaps, one still fears their excess—
how much more so if one aids and indulges them?
Thus, one lives a life without salvation.
When calamity has already taken form,
it cannot be rectified or rescued.

Seeing the small is clarity—
when form is shaped, enlightenment follows.
Guarding softness is strength—
the accumulation of weakness leads to this.
Using its radiance, one returns to its clarity.
Observing the law of guarding the Mother to preserve the child,
one attains the law and collects vision to guard the center.
Seeing the small, guarding the soft—
this is the law.
Without inviting bodily harm,
one avoids self-inflicted calamity.
This is called *xi chang*—
the hidden path to eternal life.

If I, a solitary and upright man, were to act in the Great Way,
solitary and unyielding—
if I were to see the division of the world,
I would make the straight path prevail throughout the world.
Only the upright dare fear—
only the solitary uphold rectitude—
how could they fear the multitude of evils?

The Great Way is most level,
the genuine path for rulers and subjects alike.
Yet people prefer shortcuts.
In their time, they favor crooked ways,
and I, though light in power, cannot restrain them.

The court is grandly adorned—
excessive ornamentation.
The fields lie fallow—
seizing the people’s time.
The granaries are empty—
the people lack food.
Fine silks and embroideries—
the ruler’s wealth is abundant.
Wearing sharp swords—
a fondness for martial display.
Silent in feasting—
squandering precious delicacies.
Abundant wealth—
obtained through greedy accumulation.
This is called *thieving glory*—
unrighteous gain—
what is it if not theft?
Yet they show no shame,
only more boastfulness.
How can this be the Way?

Ah, indeed!
Thievery is already not the Way—
how much more so when they further pride themselves?
Truly such people are worthy of lamentation.

Those who build well cannot be toppled—
those who build a nation or establish themselves must do so with virtue.
With virtue, one’s person is secure and the nation unshaken.

Those who embrace well cannot be lost—
*lost* means failure.
The builder of a nation embraces the people,
the establisher of oneself embraces the spirit.
If both are done with virtue,
there will be no failure or loss.

Their descendants will sacrifice at the *qi* tree without ceasing.
Those who build a nation and embrace the people with virtue
will have thriving descendants,
sacrificing at the *qi* tree without interruption.

Cultivate it in the person—
its virtue becomes genuine;
cultivate virtue in the person,
and all falseness is exhausted.

Cultivate it in the family—
its virtue becomes abundant;
cultivate virtue in the family,
and blessings flow to future generations.

Cultivate it in the village—
its virtue becomes enduring;
cultivate virtue in the village,
and its influence grows ever wider.

Cultivate it in the nation—
its virtue becomes plentiful;
cultivate virtue in the nation,
and ruler and people flourish.

Cultivate it in the world—
its virtue becomes universal.
Cultivate virtue throughout the world,
and even common households may be ennobled,
with transformation reaching distant lands—
thus, they climb mountains and cross seas to pay homage.

Therefore, observe the person to understand the person,
observe the family to understand the family,
observe the village to understand the village,
observe the nation to understand the nation,
observe the world to understand the world.
But by comparing these observations,
the rise and fall become visible.

How do I know the world is thus?
From these matters—
this is how one knows.
